articles.title: TC39 Advances 3 Proposals to Stage 4
articles.description: I love seeing Rob Palmer‚Äôs tweets about TC39‚Äôs progression of JavaScript proposals and this is a good roundup from this week‚Äôs meeting in Seattle. Areas covered include near-term features like Float16Array and import defer to more distant things like Math.clamp and Error.captureStackTrace entering stage 1.
articles.author: Sarah Gooding

articles.title: Deno 2.2 Released with Quality of Life Improvements
articles.description: The Deno team took a break from taking on Oracle to get a new feature-packed release of its JavaScript runtime out. We get built-in OpenTelemetry integration, linter updates, a new interactive way to update dependencies, node:sqlite support, TypeScript 5.7, V8 13.4, and much more.
articles.author: Iwa≈Ñczuk and Jiang

articles.title: Interop 2025: Features Browser Devs Will Focus on This Year
articles.description: Interop is an ongoing process where browser devs cooperate on improving features in concert so more Web users can use those features sooner. This year‚Äôs focus points include the Storage Access API, pointer/mouse events, phasing out old mutation events, the scrollend event, URLPattern, and more JS/WASM integration.
articles.author: Nicole Sullivan (WebKit)

articles.title: Do Lake Names Reflect Their Properties?
articles.description: I know this sounds like a geographical piece, but this developer‚Äôs curiosity led to a fun blend of JavaScript and the always useful Overpass Turbo mapping tool.
articles.author: Ivan Ludvig

articles.title: React Officially Sunsetting Create React App
articles.description: This move has been bubbling for a long time now, but the React team is now officially recommending CRA-powered apps migrate to a framework (like Next.js) or build tools like Vite.
articles.author: Matt Carroll and Ricky Hanlon

articles.title: Why TypeScript 5.8's --erasableSyntaxOnly Matters
articles.description: ‚ÄúIt disables a bunch of features that I don‚Äôt think should ever have been part of TypeScript.‚Äù
articles.author: Matt Pocock

articles.title: Mastra: A TypeScript AI Framework from the Gatsby Team
articles.description: From some of the folks behind the Gatsby React framework comes a new way to build LLM-powered agents that perform various tasks, use knowledge bases, and hold memory. Think a meta-framework like Next.js but for AI agents. GitHub repo.
articles.author: Mastra

articles.title: upfetch: An Advanced fetch Client Builder
articles.description: A TypeScript library to enhance fetch with schema validation, automatic response parsing, and type-safety, while maintaining the familiar fetch API.
articles.author: Laurent Blondy

articles.title: üìÑ¬†jsPDF 3.0: Client-Side JavaScript PDF Generation
articles.description: Create tickets, documents, certificates, etc. all on the fly. There‚Äôs a live demo on the project‚Äôs homepage.
articles.author: Parallax

articles.title: Heat.js: A Heat Map Visualization Library
articles.description: Think the GitHub contributions heat map. No dependencies, small, responsive, and theme-able. There‚Äôs a live demo or its GitHub repo.
articles.author: William Troup

articles.title: Zoompinch: A Pinch-and-Zoom Experience for Vue 3 Apps
articles.description: Designed to ‚Äòfeel native‚Äô on mobile devices. Demo.
articles.author: Elya Maurice Conrad

articles.title: swrv: 'stale-while-revalidate' Data Fetching for Vue 3
articles.description: Uses a ‚Äòstale-with-revalidate‚Äô cache invalidation strategy (i.e. data is returned from cache immediately but then updated behind the scenes).
articles.author: Kong

articles.title: ExcellentExport.js: Export Table Data to Excel or CSV
articles.description: If your app/page has some data in HTML tables and you‚Äôd like to export it to CSV or XLSX without any server involvement, this could help.
articles.author: Jordi Burgos

articles.description: Last year, ESLint unveiled a plan to become a more general purpose linter and added JSON and Markdown linting in due course. The latest addition? ESLint is now a CSS linter too!
üïπÔ∏è Running Pong across 240 browser tabs is a creative combination of AppleScript and JavaScript. Next stop - Tetris?
React Native 0.78 ‚Äì Now complete with React 19.
Nano ID 5.1 ‚Äì Tiny URL-friendly unique string ID generator.
TypeScript 5.8 RC, Node.js v18.20.7 (LTS)

articles.title: Launching Interop 2025
articles.description: This year‚Äôs Interop project (an ongoing cross-browser effort to increase interoperability of key web platform features) features 19 focus areas including CSS anchor positioning, Core Web Vitals, the View Transition API, and WebAssembly. You can see the full list, with explanations, in the Interop repo and monitor progress on this dashboard. The WebKit team has shared a blog post going into even more depth and the Microsoft Edge team gives its take too.
articles.author: James Graham

articles.title: Three Approaches to the & Selector in CSS
articles.description: The & selector in vanilla CSS, now supported via CSS Nesting, allows nesting styles within a parent selector without needing preprocessors like Sass. Here‚Äôs a look at some of the nuances behind its use.
articles.author: Preethi Sam

articles.title: Learning How to Build Modern Web Extensions
articles.description: It‚Äôs easy to run into outdated docs when building extensions. Lucky for us, Hui has been through the process recently and shares some tips.
articles.author: Hui Jing

articles.title: Testing 10 JavaScript Frameworks on Their HTML Defaults
articles.description: Using a JavaScript framework is now ‚Äòthe way‚Äô for many Web site developers, but how do the popular options fare at producing valid, error free HTML?
articles.author: Jens Oliver Meiert

articles.title: Decoding CSS Selectors: :has(:not) vs :not(:has)
articles.description: When you combine CSS functions, the nesting matters - a lot.
articles.author: Polypane

articles.title: StyleObserver: A Library to Observe CSS Property Changes
articles.description: An exhaustively tested JS library from Lea Verou, designed to observe any changes to CSS properties, and deftly deflecting a mass of relevant browser bugs along the way. Project homepage.
articles.author: Lea Verou

articles.title: LaLoka Layouts: 30+ Useful Components Built with Tailwind
articles.description: Includes components not normally included in these types of component sets. For example, various fixed position elements, input add-ons, along with standard options like avatars and cards.

articles.title: Heat.js: A Heat Map Visualization Library
articles.description: Think like the GitHub contributions heat map. No dependencies, small, responsive, and themeable. There‚Äôs a live demo or its GitHub repo.
articles.author: William Troup

articles.title: scroll-snap 5.0: A Customizable Scroll Snap Implementation
articles.description: Uses requestAnimationFrame() for 60fps scrolling performance and doesn‚Äôt have any dependencies. Try it here.

articles.title: tailwind-merge 3.0: Efficiently Merge Tailwind CSS Classes without Conflicts
articles.description: Provides a way to merge Tailwind CSS classes from JavaScript without style conflicts. v3.0 is notably Tailwind CSS v4 only so don‚Äôt upgrade if you haven‚Äôt upgraded Tailwind CSS first.
articles.author: Dany Castillo

articles.title: dash.js 5.0: JS Implementation of MPEG DASH Playback for¬†Browsers
articles.description: A reference client implementation for the playback of MPEG DASH (Dynamic Adaptive Streaming over HTTP) via JavaScript in browser based environments that support the Media Source Extensions. GitHub repo.
